citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure housing four dromedary camels had excessive feces contained in it. The feces and soiled bedding
covered approximately two thirds of the primary enclosure floor. The licensee stated that the camels have been locked in
their shelter since Thursday, January 11, 2024, due to inclement weather. The lack of a clean primary enclosure has led
to contamination of the animal with feces on the front and back of the legs and can lead to irritation of the skin and/or skin
infections. Excreta must be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the
animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.

There were European starlings roosting in the shelter of the primary enclosure for two cape porcupines. There was bird
feces noted on the white porcupine and a heavy accumulation of bird feces on all surfaces of the shelter in the primary
enclosure including the food container. The lack of an effective program to eliminate the bird pests has resulted in
contamination of the primary enclosure and the porcupines contained in the primary enclosure. Bird feces can lead to
numerous disease hazards, including psittacosis, for the porcupines housed in the enclosure. A safe and effective
program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be established and maintained.
To be corrected by January 24, 2024

The primary enclosure housing two Egyptian geese, one common shelduck, two mandarin ducks and two domestic
ducks, and the primary enclosure housing a single sacred ibis have no aquatic area for swimming and/or wading. The
lack of an aquatic area for aquatic birds does not allow the birds to make normal postural and social adjustments and can
lead to malnutrition, poor condition, debility, stress, and or abnormal behavioral patterns. Primary enclosures housing
wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water
features) and a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic
areas must be of sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments,
such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from
aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Dry areas must be of sufficient size to allow each bird to make
normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression
demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Inadequate space may be indicated by evidence of malnutrition, poor
condition, debility, stress, or abnormal behavior patterns.
To be corrected by January 24, 2024
This inspection was conducted with the licensee and exit interview was conducted with the licensees family member.
Additional Inspectors:
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.131(a)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
The primary enclosure housing four dromedary camels had excessive feces contained in it. The feces and soiled bedding 
covered approximately two thirds of the primary enclosure floor. The licensee stated that the camels have been locked in 
their shelter since Thursday, January 11, 2024, due to inclement weather. The lack of a clean primary enclosure has led 
to contamination of the animal with feces on the front and back of the legs and can lead to irritation of the skin and/or skin 
infections. Excreta must be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the 
animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
There were European starlings roosting in the shelter of the primary enclosure for two cape porcupines. There was bird 
feces noted on the white porcupine and a heavy accumulation of bird feces on all surfaces of the shelter in the primary 
enclosure including the food container. The lack of an effective program to eliminate the bird pests has resulted in 
contamination of the primary enclosure and the porcupines contained in the primary enclosure. Bird feces can lead to 
numerous disease hazards, including psittacosis, for the porcupines housed in the enclosure. A safe and effective 
program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be established and maintained.  
To be corrected by January 24, 2024 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosure housing two Egyptian geese, one common shelduck, two mandarin ducks and two domestic 
ducks, and the primary enclosure housing a single sacred ibis have no aquatic area for swimming and/or wading. The 
lack of an aquatic area for aquatic birds does not allow the birds to make normal postural and social adjustments and can 
lead to malnutrition, poor condition, debility, stress, and or abnormal behavioral patterns. Primary enclosures housing 
wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water 
features) and a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic 
areas must be of sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, 
such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from 
aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Dry areas must be of sufficient size to allow each bird to make 
normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression

demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Inadequate space may be indicated by evidence of malnutrition, poor 
condition, debility, stress, or abnormal behavior patterns.  
To be corrected by January 24, 2024 
 
This inspection was conducted with the licensee and exit interview was conducted with the licensees family member. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
